Section I

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Point Source Pollution:
 
Singularly identifiable source of pollution 
such as a direct industrial 
discharge like a smoke stack or sewage outfall pipe
 
Nonpoint Source Pollution: Diffuse source of pollution
 such as caused by rainfall moving over 
and through the ground that carries natural and human-made pollutants that are finally deposited 
into lakes, rivers, wetlands, coastal waters, and even underground sources of drinking water. 
These pollutants include


•
Oil, grease, and toxic chemicals from urban runoff


•
Excess fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides from agricultural lands and residential areas


•
Bacteria and nutrients from livestock, pet wastes, and faulty septic systems


•
Salt from irrigation practices and acid drainage from abandoned mines


•
Atmospheric deposition (acid rain)
Point Source and Nonpoint Source Pollution

© 2023 Bruce Monger

“It's the largest cause of water pollution in the nation, and 
one we've barely begun to address. But there's lots you can

to

 such as household drains and runoff from urban roadways.

Heavy Metal Pollution

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Minamata Bay, Japan 
(1950s - 1960s)
Industrial mercury was discharged 
into the bay and it entered the fish 
populations that were consumed by 
the local residence leading to 
terrible 
birth defects

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Industrial Heavy 
Metal Pollution in 
Smoke Stack Exhaust

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://seas.harvard.edu/news/2023/11/human-emissions-increased-mercury-atmosphere-sevenfold#:~:text=Humans have increased the concentration,and Applied Sciences (SEAS).
Humans have increased the concentration of 
mercury in the atmosphere 
sevenfold
 since the 
beginning of the modern era around 1500 C.E.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Bioaccumulation of Heavy Metals
1.
From the lecture on trophic transfer efficiency we learned that for a fish that is just 
3 trophic steps
 away from 
phytoplankton it takes 
10
3
 
units of phytoplankton carbon
 to make 
1 unit of fish carbon
 


2.
However, In the open ocean, with 
5 trophic steps
 to commercial fish like tuna, it 
takes 10
5
 units of phytoplankton
 to 
make 
1 unit of tuna


3.
Unlike carbon, heavy metals like mercury are not easily lost in the transfer from one trophic level to the next.
4.
1 unit of tuna that is 5 trophic steps from phytoplankton has 
nearly all the mercury that was initially contained in 10
5
 units 
of phytoplankton or 
equivalently the tuna has 10
5
 higher 
concentration of mercury than phytoplankton! 
5.
Adding mercury to the ocean at even very low 
concentrations has a gigantic effect on the final 
concentration of mercury in fish because of this 10
5
 
magnification 
6.
Pregnant woman or woman of child bearing age should be 
especially careful of eating fish that reside high on the 
trophic level (e.g., tuna or swordfish)!

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Aggregation of Plastic in Subtropical Gyre Regions
See:  http://marinedebris.noaa.gov/info/patch.html
1.
Red arrows depict Ekman Transport of the surface later resulting from the Trade Winds and the Westerly Winds.


2.
Surface water converges into the center of the gyre bring floating plastic with it.


3.
The water downwells and is recycled in the center of the gyre, but the plastic remains floating at the surface and 
gets concentrated over time

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Accumulate to High Concentration

© 2023 Bruce Monger
What Are They?
 


Small plastic particles/fibers less 
than 5 mm in diameter


Where do They Come 
From?
 
•
Larger plastic that degrades 


•
Micro-beads in cosmetics


•
Synthetic clothing fibers


•
Industrial processes.
Micro-Plastic

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
They can be consumed by 
zooplankton and moved up the 
marine food web


2.
They can adsorb organics onto their 
surface and these potentially toxic 
organics can then be moved up the 
marine food chain


3.
Also consumed by corals and may 
impact coral reef systems
The Big Concern...
Micro-Plastic

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.salon.com/2021/07/20/harrowing-report-on-plastic-pollution-says-we-have-29-years-to-save-the-ocean/

new plastic enters the ocean by 
2050


This is the stated goal of 19 
countries and the European Union

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sewage Waste

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Sewage Outfall
 
Point Source Pollution

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Primary 
Treatment
: 
The simplest, and least effective, method of treatment. 
Solids in the raw 
sewage are settled out of suspension to form a sewage sludge
.  The overlying fluid fraction 
is then discharged into the environment.  Such primary treatment removes only one-third of total 
organics and virtually none of the dissolved minerals.


Secondary 
Treatment
: 
Almost all treatment plants in North America pass the effluent from 
primary treatment to secondary treatment.  In secondary treatment 
the effluent is brought into 
contact with oxygen
 and thereby allowing aerobic microorganisms to consume dissolved 
organic matter down to low levels. This 
removes up to 90% of the total dissolved organic 
compounds. But most of the nitrogen and phosphorus remains in the sewage effluent 
from secondary treatment.


Tertiary 
Treatment
:
 The combination of primary and secondary treatment removes most of the 
organic matter in sewage, but inorganic plant nutrients (nitrogen and phosphorous) remain and 
this can cause eutrophication of surface water receiving the effluent. To avoid this, a third stage 
of treatment called tertiary or advanced waste treatment is 
employed to remove plant 
nutrients.
 Several techniques are available to remove dissolved plant nutrients from sewage 
effluent, but all are quite expensive.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Note that Primary, Secondary and Tertiary
 
Sewage 
Treatment 
Facilities
 
Employ A
 
Cumulative Process
•
A Secondary Treatment 
Facility
 requires that Primary Treatment is 
done first, so a 
Secondary Treatment 
Facility
 implies that both 
solids and dissolved organics have been removed  
•
A Tertiary Treatment
 Facility
 requires that Primary and Secondary 
treatments are done first, so a 
Tertiary Treatment 
Facility
 implies 
that solid, dissolved organics 
and
 plant nutrients have all been 
removed

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Section III
Nutrient Pollution


Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations (CAFOs)
Agricultural Runoff

© 2023 Bruce Monger
“Nutrient pollution is one of 
America's most widespread, 
costly and challenging 
environmental problems, and is 
caused by excess nitrogen and 
phosphorus in the air and water.”
United States Environmental Protection Agency
https://www.epa.gov/nutrientpollution/issue
Nutrient Pollution
Streams, Rivers and Coastal Zones

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The Basic Problem with High Nutrient Loading
1.
Increased nutrient loads in coastal waters stimulates 
exceptional algal growth
.


2.
Algal biomass that accumulates in surface waters eventually dies and sinks to the bottom of the water 
column where microbes consume it — and in the process 
also
 consume oxygen
.
3.
More nutrients leads to more algae and 
this leads to more oxygen consumption. 
4.
Oxygen concentration near the bottom of 
the water column is drawn down to 
hypoxic (low O
2
) or anoxic (no O
2
) levels 
when large amounts of algal biomass sink 
into deep coastal waters and is 
subsequently consumed by microbes.


5.
Hypoxic/Anoxic conditions lead to the 
suffocation of any and all aerobic (oxygen 
consuming) organisms - including fish.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
The world-wide flux of nitrogen 
to the coastal ocean 
environment has risen sharply 
over the past several decades...
Nitrogen Flux to the 
Coastal Ocean

© 2023 Bruce Monger
BRIC Nations = Brazil, Russia, India and China


OECD Nations = Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development  (about 30 democracies)
A close connection exists between global increases in 
nitrogen flux to the coastal environment and global increases 
in fertilizer consumption.


Increased fertilizer demand is largely driven by 


•
Human population increases


•
Increases in per capita meat consumption


•
Increases in corn ethanol production


•
A transition to Industrial Farming Practices

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://na.unep.net/geas/getUNEPPageWithArticleIDScript.php?article_id=92
Growth of population and meat supply, indexed 
1961=100 (FAO 2012a, UN 2012)
Large increases in global fertilizer use are 
driven in part by increases in grain 
production (
e.g., corn and soy
) needed 
to support an increase in global meat 
consumption. 


Growth in global meat consumption is 
outpacing human population growth 
because of increases in per capita meat 
consumption in developing countries.
Increased Meat Production 
is a Large Driver of 
Increased Fertilizer Use

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1.
To meet the rising global demand for cheap protein, livestock production has grown 
increasingly more industrialized.
 

2.
According to a United Nations FAO report, the amount of animal production derived using 
industrial factory methods: 
•
three-quarters
 of the world's poultry supply, 


•
half
 of the pork,


•
two-thirds
 of the eggs 


3.
Currently, more than 
two-thirds of all agricultural land is devoted to growing feed for 
livestock,
 while only 8 percent is used to grow food for direct human consumption.
Stanford Woods Institute for the Environment:

Important Contributor to Increased Fertilizer Pollution...

•
estimated to be 7,920 square kilometers - the sixth smallest

Summer: 2023

© 2023 Bruce Monger
http://www.grida.no/graphicslib/detail/dead-zones-and-fertilizers_04bd

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs)
1.
A few dozen naturally occurring species of 
phytoplankton (mainly dinoflagellates, but 
also diatoms and cyanobacteria) produce 
toxic chemicals that can kill other marine life 
including fish, birds and mammals.


2.
The large blooms of these kinds of algae 
(Harmful Algal Blooms) are sometimes called 
red tides or brown tides.


3.
Most toxic blooms are produced by just few 
species.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Toxins contained in harmful algal blooms can accumulate to high concentration 
at higher trophic levels and lead to the death of fish, seals, whales and humans

© 2023 Bruce Monger
•
PARALYTIC SHELLFISH POISONING
 
caused by saxitoxin


•
AMNESIC SHELLFISH POISONING
 
caused by domoic acid


•
DIARRHETIC SHELLFISH POISONING
 
caused by okadaic acid
1.
Different Toxic Phytoplankton Species Produce Different Types of Toxin.  


2.
Intense
 blooms can kill a wide-range of marine life 


3.
Toxins are concentrated to high levels in shellfish so 
even modest blooms
 
can be harmful to humans that consume shellfish that have been growing 
on waters with low-level blooms

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Status and Trends
1.
Harmful algal blooms, including highly toxic species, have increased in 
frequency, intensity, and severity in U.S. coastal areas over the past 
several decades. 


2.
There is evidence suggesting that the increases in frequency and 
intensity of harmful algal blooms is tied in increases in nutrient fluxes.


3.
This is a growing threat to U.S. coastal resources, coastal economies, 
and public health.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
HABs in marine systems are mainly caused by certain 
species of dinoflagellates and diatoms.


HABs in freshwater systems are mainly caused by certain 
species of cyanobacteria (aka. blue-green algae)
https://www.epa.gov/nutrientpollution/harmful-algal-blooms
Harmful Algal Blooms are a Growing Environmental 
Problem for 
Both
 Coastal and Freshwater Systems

© 2023 Bruce Monger

Beef has an overall water footprint of roughly 
four million gallons per ton produced.  
By contrast, the water footprint for “sugar 
crops” like sugar beets is about 52,000 gallons 
per ton; for vegetables it’s 85,000 gallons per 
ton; and for starchy roots it’s about 102,200 
gallons per ton produced.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
“Changing one’s diet to 
replace 50 percent of animal products
 with edible 
plants like legumes, nuts and tubers results in a 
30 percent reduction
 in an 
individual’s food-related water footprint.”


“Going vegetarian, a better option in many respects, reduces the water 
footprint by almost 60 percent.”
http://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/08/opinion/meat-makes-the-planet-thirsty.html?_r=0

Lowers Freshwater Demand...

Greenhouse Gas Production From Meat Production

© 2023 Bruce Monger
1. An FAO report published in 2006 titled Livestock's 
Long Shadow: Environmental Issues 
and Options
 is generally regarded as the starting point for most discussions of 
livestock’s contributions to total GHG emissions. The FAO report estimates that 
livestock contributes 
18%
 of total annual GHG emission.  
 
2. A newer FAO report in 2013 puts the livestock contributes 
14.5%
 to total annual GHG 
emission, similar to the amount generated by all transport put together.


3. Current estimates suggest that the food system–a cradle-to-grave global network that 
grows, distributes, recycles, consumes, and disposes of resources for food production–
generates 
21–37%
 of GHG emissions each year (CO
2 
equivalent (eq)) [1,2]. 
Relative Contribution of Livestock Production to Overall 
Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions
1.
Climate change responses benefit from a global food system approach. 
Nature Food. 2020; 1(2):94–7. 


2.
Food systems are responsi- ble for a third of global anthropogenic GHG emissions. 
Nature  Food . 2021; 2(3):198–209.

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.ipcc.ch/srccl/
The report states with high confidence  
that balanced diets featuring plant-based 
and sustainably produced animal-sourced 
food 
present major opportunities for 
adaptation and mitigation
 while 
generating significant co-benefits in terms 
of human health.


By 2050, dietary changes could free up
 
several million square kilometers of 
land
, and reduce global carbon dioxide 
emissions by up to 
eight billion tons per 
year
, relative to business as usual.
https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-02409-7
IPCC Special Report on Climate 
Change and Land (2019)

© 2023 Bruce Monger
https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/10/24/pork-beef-diet-climate-impact/
Optional Reading...

© 2023 Bruce Monger
Results reveal a high-end capacity of 33 gigatonnes of net 
negative emissions per annum via complete food system 
transformation, which assumes full global deployment of 
behavioral management
 
and
 
technology-based 
interventions
. 


The most promising technologies
 for achieving net negative 
emissions include hydrogen-powered fertilizer production, 
livestock feeds, organic and inorganic soil amendments, 
agroforestry, and sustainable seafood harvesting practices. 


On the consumer side
, adopting flexitarian diets cannot 
achieve full decarbonization of the food system but has the 
potential to increase the magnitude of net negative emissions 
when combined with technology scale-up. 
An Important Paper Co-Authored by 
Ben Houlton (CALS Dean) — Optional

© 2023 Bruce Monger
